pulls.title: -02: Add modeler/implementer nudging from May 2025 discussion
pulls.author: cabo

comments.author: EskoDijk
comments.body:
The "library" aspect is not fully explained, I think. The referenced docs mention a server or a device can present its supported YANG modules.

Do we mean in this context here, that a vendor can use a YANG library for a different purpose i.e. to show what YANG modules the vendor has defined in its private PEN space? (So: not what a single device would support.)
If so, we may be explicit about this?

comments.author: cabo
comments.body:
> The "library" aspect is not fully explained, I think. The referenced docs mention a server or a device can present its supported YANG modules.

Indeed, this text assumes that the concept of a YANG library or the CoRECONF specific version of that is known.

> Do we mean in this context here, that a vendor can use a YANG library for a different purpose i.e. to show what YANG modules the vendor has defined in its private PEN space? (So: not what a single device would support.) If so, we may be explicit about this?

That was not the intention -- the intention was to help a client deal with the specific PEN-based SIDs employed by a server.  Only the first bullet addresses finding all models with PEN-based SID files for a PEN holder.

comments.author: EskoDijk
comments.body: @cabo Ok, thanks. The 2nd bullet does say "implementations" which matches well to "devices" - so should be clear then it's a YANG-library of a given device, hosted on the device.

pulls.title: Security Considerations: Point to RFC 9595 and 9254, explain how...
pulls.author: cabo
pulls.body: ...PEN-based SIDs might add a detail to that.
